prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Types of actions transferred—Importance of type of action

para.paratext: The statute permits transfer of actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings without regard to the type of actions involved. Actions arising under any substantive area of the law or under any statute may be transferred. The type of actions involved in a given motion for transfer should not directly affect the Panel's transfer decision. Nonetheless, the types of actions transferred by the Panel in the past may offer some insight into the Panel's likely treatment of future cases. This section is intended only to offer a convenient means of determining the types of cases that have been transferred by the Panel. The specific factors bearing on the transfer decision, which are discussed in § 5:17 of this book, should be used to determine if transfer is appropriate or likely in a particular case.

The Panel does not rely heavily on the type of action in determining the transfer question, however, and the type of action involved should only be considered with care. Certain classes of cases are, however, likely to present similar issues to the Panel and their similarities should be readily discernible to the attorneys involved. The type of action may also correlate with factors to which the Panel does give weight. For example, multiple securities cases often involve overlapping national class actions, a factor that strongly favors centralization.

Panel decisions are, however, rendered by seven jurists with deep experience in and, presumably, devotion to, the common law. The inevitable result of this is a decision process that looks backward to determine in any case what would be consistent with earlier decisions. The type of case is one obvious basis for assessing similarity to earlier decisions. The Panel has increasingly cited this as as reason to order transfer.[1] The Panel occasionally takes pains to explain why it is not transferring a docket that is similar to an earlier docket where transfer was ordered, or why it is transferring a docket similar to one where transfer was previously denied.[2] Similarly, the Panel has pointed to earlier denials of transfer as a basis for denying transfer in a pending docket.[3]

The Panel comprises seven experience jurists, each of whom is experienced in the common law and devoted in some degree to stare decisis. Although most Panel decisions are not truly precedential, at least not in the sense that they announce rules of law that must be followed in other cases, the Panel is guided by its earlier decisions, and often will cite its earlier decisions o issues before it. In one case it noted that it had previously denied centralization where a settlement had been reached, at least in principle.[4]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
